comments.commentBody: Can't emphasize enough the water thing. It's not just about the power of the water (though of course that's primary). Once in a serious storm at night, I tried to make a u-turn in a church parking lot. I hit a deep puddle and, because of how the serpentine belt is oriented in my car, it got wet, slipped, and I lost power steering. It was only momentary, but deeply unsettling how quickly I went from just fine to uh-oh! Of course it's no tragedy to lose power steering, but unless you've been driving a classic car, you forget how much effort it takes to maneuver a car without it. I essentially lost control of the car, in the dark, with no clue about how much deeper the water could be.  I can only imagine multiplying my panic however-many-fold in a real flood or hurricane, etc.

My wife and I lived in Rockledge, Florida, slightly north of Melbourne, in Brevard County, up until few years ago. If we had been there, on Thurloe Drive (where our home used to be), we'd be under evacuation orders (Zone 5). We were always well prepared because we have lived in every disaster area you can think of: earthquakes and brush fires (Norther and Southern California) ; tornadoes and blizzards (Iowa, and my wife was also in Kansas) and then of course flooding and hurricanes (Florida, and now in Texas).

Heed the warnings...they are not a joke. Once my wife, in a mild storm, drove across a flooded street in Iowa that only had three inches of rain, but that was enough to make her car skid seriously. Once on our way to Minnesota, the weather was warm $ sunny when we started, we ran right into a blizzard. We, who follow weather information closely, forgot that day to listen to the Minnesota weather station in the car. Believe us, weather can go from normal and manageable to serious and severe in twenty minutes. This is true for hurricanes too. Until the fat lady sings you don't know if hurricane's eye is going to come right over your town or 60 miles away. Do not take the warnings lightly.

We always kept emergency supplies packed and ready 24/7. We also kept a box of blankets, jackets, some dried clothes, water, dried food, protein shakes flashlight, radio, batteries and a first aid kit in the car, so we can get going at short notice. Do that!

It would be simplistic or a confirmation error to over generalize....however- it is uncommon to find more than a small minority's of pediatricians, neurologists, psychiatrists et al who are rigid, concrete, dogmatic, authoritarian, elitist, hierarchical, paternalistic, or individualistic.
As the GOP has become dominated by extreme right wing Ayn Randian social positions and Hayekian trickle down economic theory, challenging science, climate change, gun violence, environmental toxins, social determinants of health, and the destructive momentum of income inequality- rational physicians who are in direct contact with human reality, communities, suffering and accountability will favor progressive policies.

Beth:

I'm not sure what your diatribe is about. Physicians are professionals. The traditional professions are law, medicine, dentistry, architecture and accounting. A substantial part of medical education is scientifically based but ethics, legal matters, psycho-social issues and practice management are also part of the training. Lack of any "brain dead social science" knowledge among physicians is a detriment that would hurt the patient but also the bottom line.

It also appears that you do not understand the distinction between academics like psychologists and physicians like psychiatrists. Perhaps you should take a look at the textbook of the 2000 (year) Nobel Prize winner in Medicine, psychiatrist Dr. Eric Kandel, titled "Principles of Neural Science." Let's see how many pages an engineer can get through of this book for psychiatrists, neurologists, neurosurgeons, radiologists, pathologists, geneticists and other neuroscientists. Not many, I'm sure.

Christine, you are partly incorrect. Yes, psychologicsts are not physicians. While in MOST states, psychologists cannot prescribe, there are several states mainly in the southwest where they can do so with extended training. I am opposed to this; I am a psychiatrist and know that lack of knowledge of basic medicine ad prescribing medications is a dangerous combination.

Doctors and particularly surgeons are men and women of science and high intelligence. Their strength in math and science is a result of good logical thinking skills, which gives them practical wisdom. As such, they don't easily fall prey to dogma. While all the brain dead social science majors are busy chasing the pointless revolution and getting indoctrinated in college, pre-med majors are busy getting a real education and honing their critical thinking skills at he library.

By the way psychology is not a real science, it's a branch of "social science" which to an engineer like me is pure pseudo science. That's why all the drugs prescribed by psychologists cause more trouble than they cured.

I did not get into medicine but I do high risk and high skill work as a surgeon and believe in getting compensated fairly. Heart surgeons deserve more than $800000 (I am not a heart surgeon). As a geriatrician, you have no idea of the occupational risk and skill required for a heart surgeon. Compare that compensation to people in Finance Sector and Tech Sector.
Thank you for sharing the valuable info you can. Your experience may save another the same kind of heartbreak and injury. Take good care...

Take all those photos of your home and put them in the cloud. Scan your papers and put them in the cloud. Put your paper and hard drives in your car and LEAVE! Organization is useless if you drown.
As a New Orleanian, I've been to The Apocalypse. I talked to plenty of people there. You need to evacuate. People do die needlessly.

Do all the record keeping in May. Keep your deeds and papers in a fireproof waterproof strong box ready to go. Get an offsite backup that backs up your computers over the web every night. Having your computer backed up hundreds of miles away is something you'll be happy about one day, even with your back up drives in hand. Life after a Katrina/Rita/Sandy gets rough.

Thirty people came to my country house. If you do that, bring pillows, towels, etc. Think camping indoors. People don't have the resources of a hotel. And bring the clean laundry, you'll want it. Same in a shelter. After Katrina the stores had bare shelves for months because of demand, don't count on buying stuff. I know more, much more, but even thinking about it is upsetting.

If there is any extra space in your freezer, fill 1/2 gallon and gallon jugs, even empty box-wine plastic liner bags, with water, and lay them flat.  The less airspace there is in your freezer, the longer things will hold.  And if you have a generator, you can use those large chunks or blankets of ice to keep things cold in an ice chest, and trade them back into the freezer for re-solidifying every 12 hours.

Put perishables in the freezer and refrigerator into garbage bags. If the power is out for days, it's easier to get rid of them and less odor. Try to find ice- refrigerated and frozen foods can stay cold for a few days if you dont open the door much. Candles and lights are great, games and books also- it's hard to be in the dark all night without anything to do
Try to find an elevated spot for your car. Leaving is really the best option for you and your car.
Gas up the car, and get cash- the atm machines may not work.
Better? Make sure it's all backed up in a cloud or offsite service. Which you should be doing anyway. Objects get very ephemeral in a disaster but data on distant servers is there after the storm.
Be aware that a Public Adjustor will take a percentage of the insurance settlement as his fee.

My advice following a horrible experience in the aftermath of  "Irene": don't  bother trying to deal with insurance companies on your own. In big situations like this, you get totally screwed. The first thing you should do before placing a claim, is to hire an adjuster. They are the pros who are acting on YOUR behalf. If you wouldn't go to court without a lawyer, don't try to place an insurance claim without an adjustor who works for you.

The news tells you. Listen to the radio. Bring pillows and sleeping bags and such, pets need to be in carriers or kennels. Bring pet food.
If you get to a town inland the cops can direct you, or call 211. If you want a hotel, call for a reservation. Then you know where you're going. And that you're in.

Are you a pediatrician? I'm not but I remember my peds rotations. Aside from the medical side of things, I can see pediatrics being difficult in the sense that when you deal with sick children there might be less of them but some are very, very sick and have issues stemming from birth; secondly, pediatricians deal with families and social issues a lot more than other fields. When your patient cannot communicate well with you and consent has to be given by a parent/ guardian, not to speak of parents and guardians who don't take responsibility for their child, things can get very complicated, very quickly.

Doctors, whether in medicine or surgery, are really an afterthought in America when it comes to wealth.  Even the smartest and most successful surgeons, presumably at the top income rungs in medicine, make relatively little compared to equally smart and successful lawyers, bankers and such. Medicine used to attract the best and brightest when it paid very well.  Now we get the reasonably smart and fairly motivated.  As the mean incomes of doctors continue to decline, along with the autonomy and prestige of the profession, I suspect we will learn to be happy with medical students who are not entirely stupid and just short of lazy.  Consider even now that a graduate of Harvard Law who finishes in the top 10% of her class and goes to work for a corporate law firm in New York will make more as a first year associate at age 22 than a similar top graduate of Harvard Med who enters internal medicine will at age 40, after an additional half dozen years of training, and a decade of working.  Also, the income of the top doctor will likely never rise above this level, the starting salary of the lawyer.  My patients who are financial advisors note that doctors are not very useful clients as they tend to have hardly any money.  No kidding.

Publication in the National Academy of Sciences is another sad moment for science. There are many flaws in this design across selection bias, exclusion of data, and creation of the key variable. Even if there are significant differences in the few contrived scenarios, this is not likely to be relevant in the real world. The authors minimized the six scenarios where physicians were in agreement - as has the media. The flaws begin with the political categorization. For example in states where one party dominates, those who desire to have voter impact on the primary elections will belong to the dominant party regardless of their political affiliation. Also many do not vote and their political affiliation may have changed (with age or other reasons). The authors have expressed a clear bias that they think that political affiliation shapes patient care decisions. They have stated that physicians do not leave bias behind during visits and they set out to demonstrate this. They clearly have structured their scenarios, their analysis, and their writing this direction. The scenario does not allow the physician to pick up verbal cues, relationships, resources, appearance, or other contributors to decision-making. There are insufficient limitations expressed for such a study.

The problem with your theory is that medical students with the most debt are more likely to go into the lower paying specialties.  If medical school debt was the reason why higher paying specialties are the most popular, one would expect that those with the most debt would go into these.
